title: Kingston Flyer sold to mystery buyers
text:
Kingston Flyer sold to mystery buyers HANNAH MCLEOD Last updated 12:17, February 23 2017 Barry Harcourt 
The Kingston Flyer when it was running. 
The Kingston Flyer has been sold unconditionally to mystery buyers, and it remains unclear whether the historic train will remain in the area. 
A spokesman for the investors, Adrian Chisholm, confirmed the unconditional sale on Thursday. 
Settlement would happen later in 2017, and the buyers had a "completely open mind to all options," he said. Supplied 
The Kingston Flyer sitting unused in Kingston in 2015. 
Chisholm said the buyers were "local to the district" but would not comment further on their identity. 
READ MORE: 
The Kingston Flyer and associated land and buildings had been offered for sale by its owner, David Bryce, for $2 million in May 2016, and in July it was revealed there were "several" potential buyers. AMBER-LEIGH WOOLF/FAIRFAX NZ 
Southern Steam Train Charitable Trust chairman Lindsay Buckingham with a 1/6th model replica of an AB class locomotive. 
Bryce had owned the Flyer since 2011. 
Chisholm said two AB locomotives, about 80 hectares of land, and buildings associated with the Flyer were included in the deal. 
But whether the Flyer would run again, and whether it would stay in the region was still being considered. 
The buyers would be consulting with key stakeholders and businesses in the area to help make a decision on what to do with the Flyer, Chisholm said. Ad Feedback 
"The current focus is on how to enhance the tourism activities of the region in conjunction with new operators. 
"Opportunities include the reopening of the Kingston Tavern, Bar and Caf√©, and various retail and tourism accommodation uses for the prime 4.6ha land title at Fairlight Station adjoining the world renown fishing spot, the Mataura River," he said. 
"Ongoing discussions are also being held with several parties investigating building a movie studio in the region. 
"A transport museum and static displays of the rolling stock are being considered and the current turntable and water tank at the Kingston station are to be preserved long term." 
TRUST MISSES OUT 
Southern Steam Train charitable trust chairman Lindsay Buckingham said the trust was not the mystery buyer. 
"We weren't as far advanced in our studies [as the buyer was], we were not yet in a position to make an offer," he said. 
While he was disappointed the Flyer had sold to another party, the trust was pleased it had a new owner who would hopefully fully restore the Flyer and the railway. 
"We hope that it does not suffer the same fate as other ventures before it," Buckingham said. 
Based on the research the trust had carried out, Buckingham believed a "substantial investment" would be required to get the Flyer back up and running. 
"We'd like to see it as a complete railway ... we'd hate to see it broken up and spread across the country." 
Buckingham said the trust would be open to discussions or a potential partnership with the new buyers, he said. - Stuff
